claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination induces type I interferon signaling and broadens the MHC-I peptidome.

evidence.quote: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination triggers local innate sensing and type I interferon signaling.
A broader peptide repertoire appears on MHC-I, improving tumor visibility to T cells.

claims.caveat: Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.

claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination sensitizes tumors to anti-PD-L1 immune checkpoint blockade.

evidence.quote: PD-L1 pathway activity also increases, creating a rationale for combining with checkpoint blockade.
Combined intervention improves tumor control in mice and aligns with better outcomes in the retrospective human cohort.

claims.caveat: Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.

claims.claim: The sensitization mechanism is dependent on type I interferon signaling.

evidence.quote: Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.
Lipid particle controls lacking mRNA did not reproduce the sensitization effect.

claims.caveat: Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.

claims.claim: Retrospective human data suggests prior mRNA vaccination improves outcomes for ICI-treated metastatic patients.

evidence.quote: Translational arm: a retrospective cohort of metastatic patients receiving ICI treatment, compared by prior SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination status.
Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment

claims.caveat: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.
